articles.headline: Harris Lays Out Her Economic Vision, Casting Trump’s as Backward-Looking
articles.snippet: In her first major policy speech, the vice president argued that her Republican opponent was too focused on the past, painting herself as someone who would protect the middle class for generations.
articles.abstract: In her first major policy speech, the vice president argued that her Republican opponent was too focused on the past, painting herself as someone who would protect the middle class for generations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris unspooled her economic agenda on Friday in her first major policy address, casting her vision as one for the future and former President Donald J. Trump’s as of the past, as she argued that she would improve the lives of middle-class Americans and benefit generations of their descendants.
articles.byline: By Erica L. Green, Jim Tankersley and Nicholas Nehamas

articles.headline: When N.F.L. Dreams End, NASCAR’s Pit Crews Beckon
articles.snippet: In NASCAR, victory — and money — is often determined by seconds, one reason car racing teams are increasingly looking to hire former college athletes.
articles.abstract: In NASCAR, victory — and money — is often determined by seconds, one reason car racing teams are increasingly looking to hire former college athletes.
articles.lead_paragraph: D.J. Twitty was taking it all in: the jackmen lifting the racecars, the whizzing of air guns screwing in lug nuts, the slinging of 50-pound wheels. For a South Carolina native like the 24-year-old Twitty, the cacophonous scene was just this side of paradise.
articles.byline: By Ken Belson and Travis Dove

articles.headline: For Abortion Providers, a Tough Business Gets Even Tougher
articles.snippet: After the fall of Roe v. Wade, some clinics thought they could expand their businesses in states that still allowed them to operate. It hasn’t quite worked out that way.
articles.abstract: After the fall of Roe v. Wade, some clinics thought they could expand their businesses in states that still allowed them to operate. It hasn’t quite worked out that way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Providing abortion services has always been a difficult business, with tiny-to-nonexistent profit margins and often-challenging logistical obstacles. And the Supreme Court’s decision in Dobbs v. Jackson two years ago, which eliminated the constitutional right to an abortion, has made the landscape of reproductive services even tougher.

articles.headline: Deploying on U.S. Soil: How Trump Would Use Soldiers Against Riots, Crime and Migrants
articles.snippet: The former president’s vision of using the military to enforce the law domestically would carry profound implications for civil liberties.
articles.abstract: The former president’s vision of using the military to enforce the law domestically would carry profound implications for civil liberties.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the turbulent summer of 2020, President Donald J. Trump raged at his military and legal advisers, calling them “losers” for objecting to his idea of using federal troops to suppress outbreaks of violence during the nationwide protests over the police murder of George Floyd.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: The Confidants Guiding Harris for the Most Important Days of Her Life
articles.snippet: The vice president’s brain trust is younger, more racially diverse and larger than President Biden’s. Her advisers can expect a lot of phone calls in the coming weeks.
articles.abstract: The vice president’s brain trust is younger, more racially diverse and larger than President Biden’s. Her advisers can expect a lot of phone calls in the coming weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Her revamped presidential campaign has quickly added loyalists from her 2019 primary bid. Her former aides have returned to write a convention speech and see her through a debate against Donald J. Trump. Her sister flew to Washington, joining her as she made a pork roast and marinated over her choices for a running mate.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers, Erica L. Green and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Harris Puts Four Sun Belt States Back in Play, Times/Siena Polls Find
articles.snippet: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are in close races across Arizona, Georgia, Nevada and North Carolina, crucial swing states that Mr. Trump had seemed en route to run away with just a few weeks ago.
articles.abstract: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are in close races across Arizona, Georgia, Nevada and North Carolina, crucial swing states that Mr. Trump had seemed en route to run away with just a few weeks ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has stormed into contention in the fast-growing and diverse states of Arizona, Georgia, Nevada and North Carolina, not long after Donald J. Trump had seemed on the verge of running away with those states when President Biden was still the Democratic nominee.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Ruth Igielnik

articles.headline: A Vice Presidential Learning Curve: How Kamala Harris Picked Her Shots
articles.snippet: As President Biden’s understudy, Ms. Harris did not often get to lead on signature issues. But she found roles to play on abortion rights, gun safety and a Supreme Court appointment.
articles.abstract: As President Biden’s understudy, Ms. Harris did not often get to lead on signature issues. But she found roles to play on abortion rights, gun safety and a Supreme Court appointment.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a draft of a blockbuster Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade leaked in 2022, Vice President Kamala Harris met with Ron Klain, then the White House chief of staff, in her West Wing office. He had an idea: She should lead a new task force on abortion rights.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: The Hotelification of Offices, With Signature Scents and Saltwater Spas
articles.snippet: Hoping to lure workers back to their desks, companies are designing “work resorts,” luxe spaces meant to compete with the comforts and versatility of their living room.
articles.abstract: Hoping to lure workers back to their desks, companies are designing “work resorts,” luxe spaces meant to compete with the comforts and versatility of their living room.
articles.lead_paragraph: Visitors to the Springline complex in Menlo Park, Calif., are surrounded by a sense of comfort and luxury often found at high-end hotels: off-white walls with a Roman clay finish, a gray-and-white marble coffee table and a white leather bench beneath an 8-by-4 resin canvas etched with the words “Hello, tomorrow.” Springline’s signature scent — hints of salty sea air, white water lily, dry musk and honeydew melon — linger in the air.

articles.headline: How A.I. Can Help Start Small Businesses
articles.snippet: Entrepreneurs say use of artificial intelligence for a variety of tasks is accelerating the path to hiring and, ideally, profitability.
articles.abstract: Entrepreneurs say use of artificial intelligence for a variety of tasks is accelerating the path to hiring and, ideally, profitability.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sean Ammirati has been teaching a class on entrepreneurship for more than a decade.

articles.headline: Venezuelans Mourn Loved Ones Killed in Protests, and Last Shreds of Democracy
articles.snippet: The nation is in anguish as it buries its dead and enters a new era of authoritarianism.
articles.abstract: The nation is in anguish as it buries its dead and enters a new era of authoritarianism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeison Gabriel España left home on July 28 to vote for the first — and last — time in his brief life.

articles.headline: Defying Crisis in Local News, The Star Tribune Expands
articles.snippet: The newspaper in Minneapolis is expanding its statewide coverage and changing its name to The Minnesota Star Tribune.
articles.abstract: The newspaper in Minneapolis is expanding its statewide coverage and changing its name to The Minnesota Star Tribune.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many metropolitan newspapers across the country have narrowed their ambitions in recent years, closing regional bureaus and cutting back statewide coverage in an effort to trim costs.

articles.headline: ‘Bad Blood’ Stalks a Lithium Mine in Serbia
articles.snippet: A Rio Tinto mine that Europe sees as a critical source for electric vehicle batteries has been the target of enormous protests. “I don’t need green cars. I need green apples and green grass,” said one opponent.
articles.abstract: A Rio Tinto mine that Europe sees as a critical source for electric vehicle batteries has been the target of enormous protests. “I don’t need green cars. I need green apples and green grass,” said one opponent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Their windows broken and roofs smashed, the abandoned homes in an otherwise bucolic valley carpeted with cornfields and orchards near Serbia’s border with Bosnia look like the wreckage of the Balkan wars of the 1990s.

articles.headline: JB Pritzker Is Ready to Party at a Convention He Made Happen
articles.snippet: An unusual and chaotic set of political circumstances forced Illinois’s billionaire governor to take the lead in securing the Democratic convention for Chicago.
articles.abstract: An unusual and chaotic set of political circumstances forced Illinois’s billionaire governor to take the lead in securing the Democratic convention for Chicago.
articles.lead_paragraph: The request for a bid for the Democratic National Convention had been sitting unanswered in the office of Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago for two to three weeks in the summer of 2021 when Anne Caprara, the chief of staff to Gov. JB Pritzker of Illinois, burst into the governor’s office with a Politico article saying Chicago was being courted.

articles.headline: To Undecided Voters, Harris Is Famous, but Unknown. They Want to Learn More.
articles.snippet: Vice President Kamala Harris has lit a fire among loyal Democrats. But many voters still want to know more about what she stands for.
articles.abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris has lit a fire among loyal Democrats. But many voters still want to know more about what she stands for.
articles.lead_paragraph: Teri York-Singleton is certain about one thing as she considers the November election: She will not vote for Donald J. Trump.

articles.headline: Businesses Are Already Girding for Next Phase of the U.S.-China Trade War
articles.snippet: Alarmed by the prospect of increased tariffs on Chinese goods if Donald Trump is elected, some American companies are stockpiling parts and delaying expansions.
articles.abstract: Alarmed by the prospect of increased tariffs on Chinese goods if Donald Trump is elected, some American companies are stockpiling parts and delaying expansions.
articles.lead_paragraph: If not for the trade war between the world’s two largest economies, Easy Signs would now be hiring dozens of workers at its factory in Allentown, Pa. It would be readying plans to build a second plant somewhere out West — Salt Lake City was a contender — generating another 100 jobs.

articles.headline: The Mennonites Making the Amazon Their Home
articles.snippet: Groups of Mennonites, seeking inexpensive land far from modern life, are carving out new colonies in the Amazon. They are also raising fears that they are adding to the deforestation of the vital jungle.
articles.abstract: Groups of Mennonites, seeking inexpensive land far from modern life, are carving out new colonies in the Amazon. They are also raising fears that they are adding to the deforestation of the vital jungle.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of living in jungle tents, the handful of Mennonite families trying to make a new home deep in the Peruvian Amazon began to despair. Wasps attacked as they tried to clear forest. Heavy rains turned the road to their camp to mud.
articles.byline: By Mitra Taj and Marco Garro

articles.headline: Coal Power Defined This Minnesota Town. Can Solar Win It Over?
articles.snippet: One of the nation’s largest coal-fueled electric plants is being replaced with thousands of acres of solar panels and a test of long-duration batteries.
articles.abstract: One of the nation’s largest coal-fueled electric plants is being replaced with thousands of acres of solar panels and a test of long-duration batteries.
articles.lead_paragraph: The past and the future of electricity in America are perhaps most visible in a Minnesota town surrounded by potato farms and cornfields.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Tim Gruber

articles.headline: Harris’s Early Campaign: Heavy on Buzz, Light on Policy
articles.snippet: On policy, the vice president is drafting off President Biden, essentially cherry-picking the most popular parts of his agenda and betting that a younger messenger can sell them to Americans.
articles.abstract: On policy, the vice president is drafting off President Biden, essentially cherry-picking the most popular parts of his agenda and betting that a younger messenger can sell them to Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton ran for president in 2016, she had more than 200 distinct policy proposals. Four years ago, Joseph R. Biden Jr. had a task force write a 110-page policy document for his White House bid.

articles.headline: Ukraine Says Its Incursion Will Bring Peace. Putin’s Plans May Differ.
articles.snippet: President Volodymyr Zelensky wants to hold Russian territory as leverage in future talks. In Moscow, many doubt the strategy.
articles.abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky wants to hold Russian territory as leverage in future talks. In Moscow, many doubt the strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In July, as he secretly readied an invasion of Russia, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine sent a very different signal in public: He wanted talks to end the war.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer, Kim Barker and Adam Rasgon

articles.headline: Warning Signs Flash in a Labor Survey as Fed Officials Watch for Weakness
articles.snippet: The New York Fed’s labor market survey showed cracks just as Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, prepares for a closely watched Friday speech.
articles.abstract: The New York Fed’s labor market survey showed cracks just as Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, prepares for a closely watched Friday speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans are increasingly worried about losing their jobs, a new survey from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York released on Monday showed, a worrying sign at a moment when economists and central bankers are warily monitoring for cracks in the job market.
